message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD117 is a protein marker that can be detected using immunohistochemistry. Flow cytometry is used to detect specific cells in a sample by their physical and chemical characteristics, but it is not specific to CD117-positive cells. Northern blot and fluorescence in-situ hybridization are used for detecting gene expression and chromosomal abnormalities, respectively, and are not appropriate for detecting CD117-positive cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Immunohistochemistry is the most appropriate test as it is used to identify specific proteins in tissue samples, including CD117, and can visualize the spatial distribution of the target protein in the biopsy specimen. Flow cytometry is used to analyze the physical and chemical characteristics of individual cells, while Northern blot and fluorescence in-situ hybridization are used for nucleic acid analysis, not protein analysis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD117 is a cell surface antigen and immunohistochemistry is the most appropriate test to determine the spatial distribution of CD117-positive cells in biopsy specimens. Flow cytometry can also be used but it requires dissociation of cells from the tissue sample. Northern blot and fluorescence in-situ hybridization are not appropriate for this purpose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Immunohistochemistry is the most appropriate test to determine the spatial distribution of CD117-positive cells in biopsy specimens, as it allows for visualization of protein expression and localization in tissue samples. Flow cytometry determines the characteristics of cells in suspension, not in tissue, and the other options (Northern blot and fluorescence in-situ hybridization) are not relevant for determining protein expression in tissue samples.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Immunohistochemistry is the most appropriate test for determining the spatial distribution of CD117-positive cells in biopsy specimens as it allows for visualization of the protein within the tissue itself. Flow cytometry tests for the presence of CD117-positive cells in a liquid sample, not spatial distribution within tissue. Northern blot and fluorescence in-situ hybridization are not appropriate tests for this purpose.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD117 is a protein encoded by the c-kit gene that is normally present on the surface of gastrointestinal stromal tumor cells. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) is the gold standard for CD117 detection in tissue samples, using antibodies to specifically bind to CD117 and allow visualization of the stained cells. Flow cytometry is typically used to analyze individual cells in suspension, and Northern blot and fluorescence in-situ hybridization are not applicable to CD117 detection. Therefore, the most appropriate test for determining the spatial distribution of CD117-positive cells in biopsy specimens is immunohistochemistry.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD117 is a transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase protein, and immunohistochemistry (IHC) is the most appropriate test for determining the spatial distribution of CD117-positive cells in biopsy specimens. Flow cytometry is typically used for analysis of cells in suspension, Northern blot is used for RNA analysis, and fluorescence in-situ hybridization is used to detect specific DNA sequences in cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD117 is a surface antigen marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) and immunohistochemistry is a reliable method to determine the spatial distribution of CD117-positive cells in biopsy specimens. Flow cytometry is used to analyze individual cells, Northern blot is used to detect RNA expression levels, and fluorescence in-situ hybridization is used for genetic analysis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD117 is a protein that can be detected by immunohistochemistry, making option B the most appropriate test. Flow cytometry doesn't provide spatial information, Northern blot is used for RNA detection rather than protein, and fluorescence in-situ hybridization is used for gene-targeting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. CD117 is a protein that is commonly expressed on gastrointestinal stromal tumors. Immunohistochemistry is the most appropriate test for visualizing and analyzing the distribution of CD117-positive cells in biopsy specimens. Flow cytometry is typically used for analyzing the properties of cells in suspension, not in tissue. Northern blot and fluorescence in-situ hybridization are not relevant to this particular scenario.
